712402f-a.text:
37th Street, 2nd Avenue to 3rd Avenue. (Before Reconstruction).
President Borough of Manhattan.

712403f-a.text:
212 to 22O E. 37th Street, south side, east of Third Avenue, showing several loft buildings. To the right and partially shown is No. 212. Adjoining same is a dual structure No. 214-216. The building bearing the date 1885 is No. 218-220. All of these are to the rear of B. Altman's garage and warehouse.
January 16, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712404f-a.text:
211, 215 and 221-27 E. 37th Strcet, north side, east of Third Avenue, showing the Jarcho Building which nay be demolished. This is an 8 story structure that has only recently repluced 3 former 3 story tenements. A Vacant lot (form.er 4 story No. 219) separates this fror: the New York Telephone Company Builoing. Note the construction activity at the latter necessitated by an easterly addition of similwr height replacing former tenements, No's 229-231.
January 31, 1939
Somach Photo ervice
New York City Sunnel Authority

712408f-a.text:
(1)
East 37th Street, south side, east from (No. 203), a point slightly east of Third Avenue, showing preparation for the Midtown-Queens tunnel entrance. This will be in the foreground and slopes gradually to pass under Second Avenue ("El" line). Beyond same appears the cleared block extending to First Avenue. A plaza is to be constructed there.
Tne New York Steam Corp. chimney projects above the St. Gabriel's branch of the New York Public Library.
June 28, 1939
Views: 1-2
P. L. Sperr

712409f-a.text:
E. 37th Street, south side, east of Third Avenue. Note the spire of the doomeu St. Gabriel's Ronan Catholic Church appearing beyond the Second Avenue "El". All of the structures to the east of B. Altman's warehouse will be demolished during
June of this year.
January 8, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

708059f-a.text:
Third Avenue, west side, south from E. 37th Street. At the left is the Third Avenue "El" structure straddling the surface car tracks. Note the Belgium block pavement and the grade to
the right leading uphill to Lexington Avenue.
Jan. 8, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority
